verses.text: Wisdom will praise herself, and in the midst of her people she will glory.
verses.comment: Wisdom is personified, much like in Proverbs. This language anticipates the later link between divine wisdom and the incarnate Word (cf. John 1:1-14), a theme important in Christian tradition.

verses.text: In the assembly of the Most High she will open her mouth, and in the presence of his hosts she will glory.
verses.comment: Wisdom proclaims her worth publicly, highlighted in the 'assembly'. This foreshadows how God's wisdom is revealed in the community of believers—the Church—as a living tradition.

verses.text: I came forth from the mouth of the Most High, and covered the earth like a mist.
verses.comment: Wisdom's origin is from God Himself, mirroring both the creative word in Genesis and the Word in John 1. Early Christian writers saw Wisdom as a foreshadowing of Christ, the eternal Son.

verses.text: I dwelt in high places, and my throne was in a pillar of cloud.
verses.comment: The association of cloud and throne alludes to God's presence in the Exodus and Temple, again tying Wisdom to the indwelling of God among His people.

verses.text: Alone I encircled the vault of heaven, and I walked in the depths of the abyss.
verses.comment: Wisdom's activity in creation foreshadows Christ's role as Creator (cf. Col. 1:16-17). Her omnipresence shows intimate knowledge of creation.

verses.text: Over waves of the sea, over all the earth, and over every people and nation I held sway.
verses.comment: Here, Wisdom has universal reach. This echoes the worldwide mission given to the Church and the universality of Christ's salvation.

verses.text: Among all these, I sought a resting place; in whose territory should I abide?
verses.comment: Wisdom seeks a dwelling among the people, similar to the way God sought to dwell with Israel. Reflects God's desire for communion with humanity.

verses.text: Then the Creator of all commanded me, and he who created me assigned my dwelling, saying, 'Make your dwelling in Jacob, and in Israel receive your inheritance.'
verses.comment: God commands Wisdom to dwell among His chosen people. This foreshadows the incarnational principle: God making His habitation with mankind through the Church.

verses.text: Before all ages, from beginning, he created me, and for all eternity I shall not cease to exist.
verses.comment: Eternal origin and continuity. The language ties to Christ's eternal existence and the view of Wisdom as pre-existent and enduring.

verses.text: In the holy tent I ministered before him, and so I was established in Zion.
verses.comment: Wisdom dwells in the Tent and Zion (the Temple), suggesting a sacramental presence. The physical location points to the spiritual assembly where God is worshipped.

verses.text: Thus in the beloved city he gave me rest, and in Jerusalem was my domain.
verses.comment: Wisdom's abiding in Jerusalem subliminally affirms the concept of a visible, central place for God's dwelling—pointing beyond to the visible unity of the Church.

verses.text: So I took root in an honored people, in the portion of the Lord, who is their inheritance.
verses.comment: Wisdom dwells among God's chosen, rooting herself in their midst. This echoes Christ's incarnation within the 'portion' or people of God.

verses.text: I grew tall like a cedar in Lebanon, and like a cypress on the heights of Hermon.
verses.comment: Cedar and cypress symbolize majesty, endurance, and divine favor—the characteristics of divine Wisdom.

verses.text: I grew tall like a palm tree in Engedi, and like rosebushes in Jericho; like a fair olive tree in the field, and like a plane tree beside the water.
verses.comment: Metaphors from Israel's landscape highlight Wisdom's beauty, fruitfulness, and life-giving nature—anticipating the spiritual fruitfulness promised to the Church.

verses.text: I gave off fragrance like cinnamon and acanthus, and I produced a scent like choice myrrh, like galbanum, onycha, and storax, like the smoke of incense in the tabernacle.
verses.comment: Fragrant imagery links Wisdom with worship—incense in the Temple is a sign of prayer and offering. The spiritual interpretation is the life of grace within the people of God.

verses.text: I spread out my branches like a terebinth, and my branches are glorious and graceful.
verses.comment: Wisdom's growth is expansive, reminiscent of the parable of the mustard seed becoming a tree (cf. Matt. 13:31-32)—a symbol of the Church's steady expansion.

verses.text: Like the vine I bud forth delights, and my blossoms become glorious and abundant fruit.
verses.comment: This verse highlights Wisdom’s generativity: not only is she beautiful like the blossoming vine, but she brings forth abundant and glorious fruit—echoing the biblical motif of fruitful abundance found in Israel’s vine imagery.

verses.text: Come to me, you who desire me, and be filled with my fruits.
verses.comment: A call to seek and be nourished by Wisdom anticipates Christ's invitation in John 6, where He offers Himself as Bread of Life—a deep spiritual connection.

verses.text: For memory of me is sweeter than honey, and the possession of me sweeter than the honeycomb.
verses.comment: Wisdom's benefits—sweetness, satisfaction—prefigure the delights found in deep communion with God and His truth.

verses.text: Those who eat me will hunger for more, and those who drink me will thirst for more.
verses.comment: The paradoxical statement shows that the pursuit of divine Wisdom is inexhaustible—a profound echo of Christ as living water and bread, whose fullness always draws us deeper.

verses.text: Whoever obeys me will not be put to shame, and those who work with me will not stumble.
verses.comment: The ethics of Wisdom: obedience leads to spiritual security. This links to Jesus’ teaching about the wise builder who hears and acts on God’s word.

verses.text: All this is the book of the covenant of the Most High God, the law which Moses commanded us as an inheritance for the congregations of Jacob.
verses.comment: Connecting Wisdom with Torah, this verse points to divine instruction handed to the people through tradition—which becomes, through Christ, the fullness of revealed faith.

verses.text: It fills men with wisdom, like the Pishon and the Tigris at the time of first fruits.
verses.comment: The rivers are symbols of life and abundance—wisdom flows into the faithful, just as sacramental grace does.

verses.text: It makes understanding abound like the Euphrates, and as the Jordan at harvest time.
verses.comment: Abundant rivers represent spiritual wisdom pouring out—also alluding to the waters of baptism as a source of new life.

verses.text: It pours forth instruction like the Nile, like the Gihon at the time of vintage.
verses.comment: By comparing wisdom's instruction to the life-giving waters of the Nile and the Gihon rivers, the text connects Wisdom to the fertility and abundance essential for the well-being of ancient societies. The mention of 'the time of vintage' evokes harvest, suggesting that wisdom brings fruitfulness and prosperity when received.

verses.text: The first man did not know wisdom fully, nor will the last one fathom her.
verses.comment: This verse asserts the unfathomable depth and mystery of divine wisdom, transcending human comprehension from the very beginning (Adam) to the end of time. It highlights human limitations and the inexhaustibility of wisdom, a recurring theme in sapiential literature.

verses.text: For her thoughts are more abundant than the sea, and her counsel deeper than the great abyss.
verses.comment: The poetic hyperbole emphasizes the inexhaustibility and profundity of wisdom. The sea and the abyss were ancient symbols for the unknowable and immense, indicating that wisdom's insights and guidance far exceed human understanding and are never fully exhausted by inquiry.

verses.text: I will again make instruction shine forth like the dawn, and will make it known far and wide.
verses.comment: The universal spread of wisdom parallels the gospel’s reach to all nations, the light of faith shines for all.

verses.text: I will pour out teaching like prophecy, and leave it to future generations.
verses.comment: Teaching as prophecy: wisdom is a living word, transmitted generation to generation by a visible, unbroken chain—hinting at a tradition that safeguards and transmits faith.

verses.text: See that I have not labored for myself only, but for all who seek wisdom.
verses.comment: Wisdom is offered freely and universally to all who seek. The closing encouragement presses the reader to receive and transmit this wisdom—shaped and safeguarded in the assembly of God's people.

verses.text: I will again pour out teaching like prophecy, and leave it to all future generations.
verses.comment: Rather than an imperative, this is Wisdom herself promising to perpetually pour out her teaching, ensuring its availability for all generations—emphasizing the enduring gift of divine wisdom.

verses.text: Observe that I have not labored for myself alone, but for all who seek wisdom.
verses.comment: This closing statement stresses the universality and accessibility of Wisdom’s labor; her treasures are offered not for herself, but for everyone who earnestly seeks understanding.
